macroeconomics.title: Macroeconomics
macroeconomics.description: Comprehensive study of macroeconomic principles, policies, and their impact on global economies

unit-1.title: Basic economics concepts
unit-1.description: Introduction to fundamental economic concepts and principles

macroecon-u1-l1-article.title: Learn: Introduction to macroeconomics
importantPoints: Economics studies how societies allocate scarce resources
Scarcity is the fundamental economic problem
Positive statements are factual; normative statements are value judgments
Economic models simplify reality to help us understand complex systems
Command economies are centrally planned; market economies rely on individual decisions

lesson-1-2.title: Opportunity cost and the Production Possibilities Curve

macroecon-u1-l2-video-4.title: PPCs for increasing, decreasing and constant opportunity cost

macroecon-u1-l2-video-5.title: Production Possibilities Curve as a model

macroecon-u1-l2-article.title: Lesson summary: Opportunity cost and the PPC
importantPoints: The PPC shows maximum production combinations when resources are fully employed
Opportunity cost is the value of the next best alternative
Increasing opportunity cost creates a bowed-outward PPC
Points on the curve are efficient; points inside are inefficient
The PPC can model a country's production possibilities and trade-offs

lesson-1-3.title: Comparative advantage and the gains from trade

macroecon-u1-l3-video-1.title: Comparative advantage, specialization, and gains from trade

macroecon-u1-l3-video-3.title: Opportunity cost and comparative advantage using an output table

macroecon-u1-l3-video-4.title: Terms of trade and the gains from trade

macroecon-u1-l3-video-5.title: Input approach to determining comparative advantage

macroecon-u1-l3-video-6.title: When there aren't gains from trade

macroecon-u1-l3-article.title: Lesson summary: Comparative advantage and the gains from trade
importantPoints: Comparative advantage is based on opportunity cost, not absolute advantage
Countries benefit from specializing in goods where they have comparative advantage
Terms of trade must be between opportunity costs for both countries to gain
Trade increases total world production and consumption
Even countries with absolute advantage in everything can benefit from trade

macroecon-u1-l3-quiz.title: Comparative advantage and the gains from trade

macroecon-u1-l4-video-2.title: Price of related products and demand

macroecon-u1-l4-video-3.title: Change in expected future prices and demand

macroecon-u1-l4-video-4.title: Changes in income, population, or other factors

macroecon-u1-l4-video-6.title: Change in demand versus change in quantity demanded

macroecon-u1-l4-article.title: Lesson summary: Demand and the law of demand
importantPoints: The law of demand shows an inverse relationship between price and quantity demanded
Substitute goods compete; complementary goods are used together
Expected future prices affect current demand
Normal goods increase with income; inferior goods decrease
Price changes cause movement along the curve; other factors shift the curve

macroecon-u1-l5-video-3.title: Change in supply versus change in quantity supplied

macroecon-u1-l5-article.title: Lesson summary: Supply and its determinants
importantPoints: The law of supply shows a direct relationship between price and quantity supplied
Higher input costs decrease supply; better technology increases supply
More sellers increase supply; fewer sellers decrease supply
Price changes cause movement along the curve; other factors shift the curve
Government policies (taxes, subsidies) affect supply

macroecon-u1-l6-video-3.title: Changes in equilibrium price and quantity when supply and demand change

macroecon-u1-l6-article.title: Lesson summary: Market equilibrium, disequilibrium, and changes in equilibrium
importantPoints: Equilibrium occurs when quantity demanded equals quantity supplied
At equilibrium, the market clears with no shortage or surplus
Demand shifts affect both price and quantity in the same direction
Supply shifts affect price and quantity in opposite directions
When both curves shift, one outcome is definite, the other is ambiguous

unit-2.title: Economic indicators and the business cycle
unit-2.description: Understanding GDP, unemployment, inflation, and business cycles

lesson-2-1.title: Gross Domestic Product (The circular flow and GDP)

macroecon-u2-l1-video-1.title: Circular flow of income and expenditures

macroecon-u2-l1-video-3.title: More on final and intermediate GDP contributions

macroecon-u2-l1-video-5.title: Income and expenditure views of GDP

macroecon-u2-l1-video-6.title: Value added approach to calculating GDP

macroecon-u2-l1-video-8.title: Expenditure approach to calculating GDP examples

macroecon-u2-l1-article.title: Lesson summary: The circular flow and GDP
importantPoints: The circular flow model shows money and resources flowing between households and firms
GDP measures total production of final goods and services within a country
Only final goods are counted; intermediate goods are excluded
GDP = C + I + G + (X - M) using the expenditure approach
GDP can be calculated using expenditure, income, or value-added approaches

macroecon-u2-l2-article-1.title: Beyond GDP: other ways to measure the economy
importantPoints: Alternative measures like HDI and GPI address GDP limitations
Green GDP adjusts for environmental costs
GNP includes income from abroad
NDP accounts for capital depreciation

macroecon-u2-l2-article-2.title: How well GDP measures the well-being of society
importantPoints: GDP doesn't measure non-market activities or quality of life
GDP doesn't reflect income distribution or negative externalities
GDP doesn't account for informal economy or sustainability
GDP measures output well but not overall well-being

macroecon-u2-l2-article-3.title: Lesson summary: The limitations of GDP
importantPoints: GDP measures output but has significant limitations
Alternative measures address GDP limitations
GDP does not capture well-being or sustainability

macroecon-u2-l3-video-2.title: Natural, cyclical, structural, and frictional unemployment rates

macroecon-u2-l3-article.title: Lesson summary: Unemployment
importantPoints: Unemployment rate = (Unemployed / Labor Force) × 100
Frictional unemployment is normal job transitions
Structural unemployment is due to skills mismatch
Cyclical unemployment is caused by economic downturns
Natural rate = Frictional + Structural unemployment

macroecon-u2-l4-video-5.title: Example question calculating CPI and inflation

macroecon-u2-l4-article-1.title: Tracking inflation
importantPoints: CPI tracks consumer prices
PPI tracks wholesale prices
GDP Deflator is a broader measure

macroecon-u2-l4-article-2.title: How changes in the cost of living are measured
importantPoints: CPI uses a representative basket of goods
Limitations include substitution bias and quality changes

macroecon-u2-l4-article-3.title: How the United States and other countries experience inflation
importantPoints: Inflation rates vary by country
Central banks typically target 2% inflation
Hyperinflation and deflation are extreme cases

macroecon-u2-l4-article-4.title: The confusion over inflation
importantPoints: Inflation doesn't mean all prices rise
Deflation isn't always bad
Moderate inflation can encourage spending

macroecon-u2-l4-article-5.title: Lesson summary: Price indices and inflation
importantPoints: Inflation is a sustained increase in the general price level
CPI measures changes in consumer prices using a basket of goods
Deflation can lead to deflationary spirals
Stagflation combines stagnation with high inflation

macroecon-u2-l5-video-1.title: Winners and losers from inflation and deflation

macroecon-u2-l5-article.title: Lesson summary: The costs of inflation
importantPoints: Inflation benefits borrowers and hurts lenders
Inflation reduces purchasing power of savings and fixed incomes
Deflation benefits lenders but can cause economic contraction
Inflation redistributes wealth between different groups
Moderate, predictable inflation is generally preferred

macroecon-u2-l6-video-3.title: Example calculating real GDP with a deflator

macroecon-u2-l6-article-1.title: Adjusting nominal values to real values
importantPoints: Real value = (Nominal value / Price index) × 100
This adjustment removes inflation effects
Allows comparison across time periods

macroecon-u2-l6-article-2.title: Lesson summary: Real vs. nominal GDP
importantPoints: Nominal GDP uses current prices; real GDP uses constant prices
Real GDP removes inflation effects to show actual production changes
GDP deflator = (Nominal GDP / Real GDP) × 100
Real GDP is better for measuring economic growth

macroecon-u2-l7-article-1.title: Tracking real GDP over time
importantPoints: Real GDP shows long-term growth trend with cyclical fluctuations
Business cycle has four phases: expansion, peak, contraction, trough
A healthy economy shows positive long-term growth with small, infrequent recessions

macroecon-u2-l7-article-2.title: Lesson summary: Business cycles
importantPoints: Business cycle has four phases: expansion, peak, contraction, trough
Recession is defined as two consecutive quarters of negative GDP growth
Real GDP shows long-term growth trend with cyclical fluctuations
Expansions feature growth, employment, and rising prices
Contractions feature decline, unemployment, and falling prices

unit-3.title: National income and price determination
unit-3.description: Understanding aggregate demand, aggregate supply, and fiscal policy

macroecon-u3-l1-article.title: Learn: Aggregate demand
importantPoints: Aggregate demand is total spending on goods and services at different price levels
AD = C + I + G + (X - M)
AD curve slopes downward due to wealth, interest rate, and foreign trade effects
AD shifts when components change for reasons other than price level
Expansionary policies shift AD right; contractionary policies shift AD left

questions.question: When the price level increases, the amount of goods and services demanded economy-wide decreases because when the price level increases, everyone's assets can purchase fewer goods and services. What is the term for the relationship described above?
options: The interest rate effect
Sticky wage theory
Misperceptions theory
The real wealth effect
The exchange rate effect
questions.explanation: The real wealth effect describes how an increase in the price level decreases the real value of assets, leading to a decrease in demand for goods and services economy-wide.

questions.question: Which of the following could cause the change shown?
options: A decrease in the price level in the United States
A decrease in investment spending in the United States
A decrease in government spending in the United States
An increase in the price level in the United States
An increase in national income in a trading partner, such as the eurozone
questions.explanation: An increase in national income in a trading partner increases exports, which causes the aggregate demand (AD) curve to shift to the right.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a component of aggregate demand (AD)?
options: Government spending
Consumption
Net exports
Investment
Wages
questions.explanation: Aggregate demand (AD) consists of consumption (C), investment (I), government spending (G), and net exports (X - M). Wages are not a component of AD, but rather a cost of production.

questions.question: When the price level increases, goods in other countries are relatively cheaper. As a result, a country's imports increase, displacing the demand for domestic production. What is the term for the relationship described above?
options: Sticky wage theory
Misperceptions theory
The exchange rate effect
The interest rate effect
The real wealth effect
questions.explanation: The exchange rate effect describes how changes in the price level affect international competitiveness and foreign trade, which in turn affects aggregate demand.

macroecon-u3-l2-article.title: Learn: Multipliers
importantPoints: MPC is the fraction of additional income spent on consumption
Spending multiplier = 1 / (1 - MPC) = 1 / MPS
Tax multiplier = -MPC / (1 - MPC)
Tax multiplier is smaller than spending multiplier
Multipliers show how spending changes are amplified through the economy

questions.question: The marginal propensity to consume (MPC) in Hamsterville is 0.75. What will be the size of the change in aggregate demand that will occur as a result of a $1 million dollar increase in the government spending component of AD?
options: $0.75 million
$4 million
$0.25 million
$3 million
$1.75 million
questions.explanation: The spending multiplier = 1 / (1 - MPC) = 1 / (1 - 0.75) = 1 / 0.25 = 4. A $1 million increase in government spending will lead to a change in aggregate demand of 4 × $1 million = $4 million.

questions.question: Fred got a year-end bonus in two different years. The table below describes how much of that bonus he spent in each year. Year 1: Bonus = $1000, Amount spent = $750. Year 2: Bonus = $2000, Amount spent = $1500. If Fred's habits represent the typical household in this country, what is the marginal propensity to save in this country?
questions.explanation: Change in bonus (income) = $2000 - $1000 = $1000. Change in amount spent (consumption) = $1500 - $750 = $750. Change in saving = $1000 - $750 = $250. Marginal propensity to save (MPS) = Change in saving / Change in income = $250 / $1000 = 0.25.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the purpose of the expenditure multiplier?
options: quantify the size of the change in aggregate demand (AD) that occurs as a result of a change in taxes
quantify the size of the change in aggregate demand (AD) that occurs as a result of a change in a component of AD
quantify the change in the size of the money supply that occurs as a result of a change in the reserve ratio
quantify the change in aggregate demand (AD) that will occur as a result of a change in government spending, but not other components of AD
quantify the change in the interest rate that will occur as a result of an increase deficit spending
questions.explanation: The expenditure multiplier serves to quantify the size of the change in aggregate demand (AD) that occurs as a result of a change in any component of AD (consumption, investment, government spending, or net exports).

questions.question: The nation of Johnsrudia has a marginal propensity to consume (MPC) of 0.9. If there is an autonomous increase in new home construction of $10 billion, what will happen to real gross domestic product (GDP)?
options: Real GDP will increase by exactly $10 billion
Real GDP will increase by exactly $9 billion
Real GDP will not change
Real GDP will increase by less than $9 billion
Real GDP will increase by more than $10 billion
questions.explanation: The multiplier = 1 / (1 - MPC) = 1 / (1 - 0.9) = 1 / 0.1 = 10. An autonomous increase in new home construction (investment) of $10 billion will lead to a change in Real GDP = Multiplier × Change in Investment = 10 × $10 billion = $100 billion. Real GDP will increase by more than $10 billion.

macroecon-u3-l3-article.title: Learn: Short-run aggregate supply
importantPoints: SRAS shows production at different price levels in the short run
SRAS slopes upward due to sticky wages and prices
Higher price levels increase production when costs are sticky
SRAS shifts when input costs, productivity, or supply shocks change
Supply shocks can shift SRAS left (adverse) or right (favorable)

macroecon-u3-l4-article.title: Learn: Long-run aggregate supply
importantPoints: LRAS is vertical at potential GDP
In the long run, all prices and wages are flexible
Price level doesn't affect real output in the long run
LRAS represents the economy's productive capacity
LRAS shifts when resources, technology, or institutions change

questions.question: Which of the following statements makes a correct distinction between the short run and the long run?
options: Short run: wages are fixed; long run: wages are fully flexible
Short run: wages are fully flexible; long run: wages are fixed
Short run: less than six months has passed; long run: more than six months has passed
Short run: aggregate supply slopes downwards; long run: aggregate supply slopes upwards
Short run: unemployment will increase in response to inflation; long run: unemployment is not affected by inflation
questions.explanation: In the short run, wages are sticky (fixed), meaning they do not adjust immediately to changes. In the long run, all prices and wages are flexible and adjust fully.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes why long-run aggregate supply is vertical at full employment output, as opposed to some other output?
options: Full employment output is the output associated with the natural rate of unemployment
Full employment output means a country has an unemployment rate lower than the natural rate
Output will always return to the level at which unemployment is zero percent
Full employment output means a country has an unemployment rate higher than the natural rate
Output more than full employment output is impossible
questions.explanation: Long-run aggregate supply (LRAS) is vertical at full employment output because this output corresponds to the natural rate of unemployment, which includes frictional and structural unemployment but not cyclical unemployment.

questions.question: The LRAS curve for Verminville is shown here. Which points correspond to a point on Verminville's production possibilities curve (PPC)?
options: Points S and U only
Point T only
Points S, T, and U
Point U only
Point S only
questions.explanation: The LRAS curve represents the economy's potential output, which corresponds to points on the production possibilities curve (PPC). Point T lies directly on the LRAS curve, representing efficient production at full resource utilization. Point S (to the left of LRAS) represents output below potential (inside the PPC), and Point U (to the right of LRAS) represents unsustainable output (outside the PPC).

questions.question: Which of the following best describes how wages respond to changes in the price level in the long run?
options: Wages do not adjust to changes in the price level
Wages fall when the price level falls and rise when the price level rises
Wages fall when the price level rises and rise when the price level falls
Wages do not change when the price level increases and wages fall when the price level decreases
Wages do not change when the price level falls and rise when the price level rises
questions.explanation: In the long run, wages are flexible and adjust proportionally to changes in the price level. When the price level falls, wages also fall, and when the price level rises, wages rise, maintaining real purchasing power.

macroecon-u3-l5-article.title: Learn: Equilibrium in the AD-AS model
importantPoints: Short-run equilibrium is where AD intersects SRAS
Long-run equilibrium is where AD, SRAS, and LRAS all intersect
Recessionary gap: Actual GDP < Potential GDP
Inflationary gap: Actual GDP > Potential GDP
Long-run equilibrium occurs at potential GDP with natural unemployment

macroecon-u3-l5-quiz.title: Quiz: Equilibrium in the AD-AS model

questions.question: What is the price level and real GDP associated with current output in the economy shown in this graph?
options: PL = 105, rGDP = $200b
PL = 107, rGDP = $200b
PL = 107, rGDP = $190b
PL = 105, rGDP = $190b
questions.explanation: Current output in the economy is determined by the intersection of the aggregate demand (AD) curve and the short-run aggregate supply (SRAS) curve. On the graph, this intersection occurs at a price level of 105 and real GDP of $200b.

questions.question: If current real gross domestic product (GDP) in this country is $170 million, what is the size of the output gap?
options: -$20 million
-$60 million
$10 million
$20 million
questions.explanation: Output gap = Actual GDP - Potential GDP. If actual GDP is $170 million and potential GDP (on the production possibilities curve) is $190 million, then output gap = $170 - $190 = -$20 million (recessionary gap).

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding the points on the production possibilities curve (PPC) shown above?
options: Point T is efficient, and point U is inefficient
Point T is inefficient, and point U is efficient
Both points T and U are efficient
Both points T and U are inefficient
Point T is unattainable, and point U is efficient
questions.explanation: Points on the production possibilities curve (PPC), such as point T, represent efficient production at full resource utilization. Points inside the PPC, such as point U, represent inefficient production or underutilization of resources.

questions.question: The graph shown here illustrates the current status of the economy in Verminville. Based on this graph, which of the following is true about Verminville?
options: The economy is in short-run equilibrium, but not in long-run equilibrium
The actual unemployment rate equals the natural rate of unemployment
The country has cyclical unemployment but no structural unemployment
The current unemployment rate is lower than the natural rate of unemployment
The economy is at a peak in its business cycle
questions.explanation: When all three curves (AD, SRAS, and LRAS) intersect at a single point, the economy is in long-run equilibrium. In this case, actual GDP equals potential GDP, and the actual unemployment rate equals the natural rate of unemployment.

questions.question: Which point or points in the graph shown here represent a short-run equilibrium level of output?
options: D
E
B
C
A
questions.explanation: Short-run equilibrium occurs at the intersection of the aggregate demand (AD) curve and the short-run aggregate supply (SRAS) curve, which is labeled as point D. The level of output at this short-run equilibrium is represented by point E on the real GDP axis, which is located directly below point D.

lesson-3-6.title: Changes in the AD-AS model in the short run

macroecon-u3-l6-video-1.title: Changes in the AD-AS model in the short run

macroecon-u3-l6-article.title: Learn: Changes in the AD-AS model in the short run
importantPoints: AD shifts change price and output in the same direction
SRAS shifts change price and output in opposite directions
Demand-pull inflation: AD increases faster than supply
Cost-push inflation: SRAS decreases (supply shock)
The model shows how growth, unemployment, and inflation are interconnected

macroecon-u3-l6-quiz.title: Quiz: Changes in the AD-AS model

questions.question: All else equal, what happens to the price level and unemployment when investment spending by firms increases?
options: Price level decreases; unemployment decreases
Price level increases, unemployment increases
Price level increases, unemployment decreases
No change in the price level; unemployment decreases
Price level increases, no change in unemployment
questions.explanation: An increase in investment spending increases aggregate demand (AD), shifting the AD curve to the right. In the short run, this causes both the price level and real GDP to increase, leading to a decrease in unemployment.

questions.question: Which of the following unambiguously leads to inflation?
options: An increase in government regulations on production and a decrease in business optimism that decreases the demand for capital
An increase in expectations of inflation and a decrease in investment spending
An increase in wages and an increase in consumer spending
Lower expectations of inflation and fewer exports
A decrease in the rental price of capital and an increase in government spending
questions.explanation: An increase in wages shifts SRAS to the left (increases costs), and an increase in consumer spending shifts AD to the right. Both of these factors unambiguously lead to an increase in the price level (inflation).

questions.question: Which of the following could cause an unanticipated increase in both the inflation rate and the unemployment rate?
options: A decrease in government regulation
A decrease in net exports
An unanticipated increase in government spending
An unanticipated increase in energy prices
An increase in personal income taxes
questions.explanation: An unanticipated increase in energy prices is a negative supply shock that shifts SRAS to the left. This causes both the price level to increase (inflation) and real GDP to decrease, leading to an increase in unemployment. This phenomenon is called stagflation.

questions.question: Which of the following leads to stagflation?
options: A positive aggregate demand (AD) shock
A positive long-run aggregate supply (LRAS) shock
A positive short-run aggregate supply (SRAS) shock
A negative short-run aggregate supply (SRAS) shock
A negative aggregate demand (AD) shock
questions.explanation: Stagflation is the combination of stagnation (high unemployment, low growth) and inflation. A negative SRAS shock (SRAS shifting left) causes both the price level to increase (inflation) and real GDP to decrease (increased unemployment), which is the definition of stagflation.

macroecon-u3-l7-article.title: Learn: Long-run self-adjustment
importantPoints: The economy automatically returns to potential GDP in the long run
Recessionary gaps cause falling wages/prices, shifting SRAS right
Inflationary gaps cause rising wages/prices, shifting SRAS left
Self-adjustment assumes flexible wages and prices
Adjustment can be slow, justifying policy intervention

questions.question: The current state of the economy of Fredland is illustrated in this graph. Which of the following best describes how the economy will adjust in the long run?
options: Aggregate demand will increase and the price level will increase
Long-run aggregate supply will increase and the price level will stay the same
Short-run aggregate supply will decrease and the price level will increase
Aggregate demand will decrease and the price level will increase
Long-run aggregate supply will decrease and the price level will not change
questions.explanation: When the economy has an inflationary gap (Y1 > Yf), low unemployment puts upward pressure on wages. Higher wages increase production costs, causing SRAS to shift left (decrease). This leads to an increase in the price level and a decrease in output back to the full employment level.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes what will happen to this economy in the long run?
options: The LRAS curve will shift out and full employment output will increase from Yf to Y1
Wages and prices will decrease and the full employment level of output will increase
Wages and prices will decrease and output will decrease from Y1 to Yf
Wages and prices will increase and output will decrease from Y1 to Yf
Wages and prices will increase and output will remain at Y1
questions.explanation: When the economy is operating above potential (Y1 > Yf), there is an inflationary gap. In the long run, low unemployment causes wages and prices to rise, shifting SRAS to the left. This causes the price level to increase and output to decrease from Y1 back to Yf (full employment output).

questions.question: The economy of Hamsterville is in long-run equilibrium. The central bank of Hamsterville decided to engage in expansionary monetary policy and to buy bonds. This action increased aggregate demand (AD). What is the long-run effect of an increase in AD on the price level and the level of output?
options: Price level increases; output increases
Price level decreases; output doesn't change
Price level increases; output doesn't change
Price level decreases; output increases
questions.explanation: In the long run, an increase in aggregate demand (AD) will lead to an increase in the price level, but the level of output will return to its natural rate (potential output). In the long run, output does not change because the economy always returns to potential GDP through self-adjustment.

questions.question: How are an increased potential output and an unchanged current output represented in the aggregate demand-aggregate supply (AD-AS) model?
options: The aggregate demand (AD) curve shifts to the right
The long-run aggregate supply (LRAS) curve shifts to the right
The money supply shifts to the right
The demand for money shifts to the right
The short-run aggregate supply (SRAS) curve shifts to the right
questions.explanation: An increased potential output means the economy can produce more at full employment. This is represented by the LRAS curve shifting to the right, showing an increase in potential GDP. Current output remains unchanged because the LRAS shift does not directly affect the current AD-SRAS equilibrium.

macroecon-u3-l8-article.title: Learn: Fiscal policy
importantPoints: Fiscal policy uses government spending and taxes to influence AD
Expansionary policy increases AD; contractionary policy decreases AD
Required change = Output gap / Multiplier
Spending multiplier is larger than tax multiplier
Tax cuts and spending increases both affect AD but have different impacts

questions.question: Before experiencing the supply shock shown in this graph, Maxistan was in long-run equilibrium. The marginal propensity to consume (MPC) Maxistan is 0.75. Which of the following is a fiscal policy action that would be the best choice to return the economy to full employment output?
options: Increase taxes by $75 million
Decrease taxes by $25 million
Increase government spending $25 million
Decrease government spending $25 million
Decrease government spending by $75 million
questions.explanation: The economy has a recessionary gap of $75 million (200 - 125). Spending multiplier = 1 / (1 - 0.75) = 4. Tax multiplier = -0.75 / (1 - 0.75) = -3. To close the gap, we need to increase GDP by $75 million. Decreasing taxes by $25 million: -3 × (-$25) = +$75 million GDP. This is the correct answer.

questions.question: Which of the following is a tool of discretionary fiscal policy?
options: International trade
Government spending on a new infrastructure project
Automatic stabilizers such as income taxes
Buying bonds
Lowering interest rates
questions.explanation: Discretionary fiscal policy is deliberate changes in government spending or taxes by the government. Government spending on a new infrastructure project is an example of discretionary fiscal policy. Automatic stabilizers work automatically, and buying bonds and lowering interest rates are tools of monetary policy.

questions.question: Which of the following would be a government spending and tax multiplier for a country?
options: Government spending multiplier equal 9 and tax multiplier equals -8
Government spending multiplier equal 10 and tax multiplier equals -5
Government spending multiplier equal 12 and tax multiplier equals -15
Government spending multiplier equal 3 and tax multiplier equals -4
Government spending multiplier equal -9 and tax multiplier equals -9
questions.explanation: The tax multiplier (k_t) and spending multiplier (k_g) are related by the formula: k_t = 1 - k_g. If k_g = 9, then k_t = 1 - 9 = -8. This is the only option that satisfies this relationship. A government spending multiplier cannot be negative.

questions.question: The nation of Xela was in long-run equilibrium but experienced the aggregate demand shock shown below. The marginal propensity to consume (MPC) inXela is 0.9. Which of the following is a fiscal policy action that would be the best choice to return the economy to full employment output?
options: Increase government spending by $2 million
Decrease taxes by $20 million
Increase government spending $20 million
Decrease spending by $2 million
Decrease government spending $20 million
questions.explanation: The economy has an inflationary gap of $20 million (120 - 100). Spending multiplier = 1 / (1 - 0.9) = 10. To close the gap, we need to decrease GDP by $20 million. Decreasing government spending by $2 million: 10 × (-$2) = -$20 million GDP. This returns the economy to full employment output.

macroecon-u3-l9-article.title: Learn: Automatic stabilizers
importantPoints: Automatic stabilizers work without explicit legislative action
They increase spending/decrease taxes during recessions
They decrease spending/increase taxes during expansions
Examples: unemployment insurance, progressive taxes, welfare
They provide timely, automatic counter-cyclical effects

questions.question: Tax revenues are an example of an automatic stabilizer. Which of the following best describes changes in unemployment and real GDP that cause tax revenue to increase?
options: Real GDP is equal to the full employment output; unemployment is less than the natural rate
Real GDP is higher than full employment output; unemployment is higher than the natural rate of unemployment
Real GDP is higher than full employment output; unemployment is equal to the natural rate
Real GDP is lower than full employment output; unemployment is lower than the natural rate
Real GDP is higher than full employment output; unemployment is lower than the natural rate
questions.explanation: Automatic stabilizers work counter-cyclically. During expansion, when real GDP is higher than full employment output and unemployment is lower than the natural rate, incomes rise, which automatically increases tax revenues. This helps control inflation by reducing disposable income.

questions.question: Hamsterville has a progressive income tax and a social insurance program that provides unemployed workers with a basic income while they are searching for jobs. What impact will this progressive tax system have on real GDP?
options: We cannot tell the impact taxes will have on real GDP
Increase real GDP during every phase of the business cycle
Decrease real GDP during the expansion phase; increase real GDP during the recession phase
Increase real GDP during the expansion phase; decrease real GDP during the recession phase
Decrease real GDP during all phases of the business cycle
questions.explanation: A progressive tax system acts as an automatic stabilizer. During expansion, higher incomes lead to higher taxes (decreasing real GDP), and during recession, lower incomes lead to lower taxes (increasing real GDP). The social insurance program also works counter-cyclically, increasing transfers during recession.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the function of automatic stabilizers in an economy?
options: They increase unemployment during recessions
They eliminate the business cycle
They ensure that budgets are balanced
They decrease tax revenues when gross domestic product decreases
They move the economy further away from full-employment output
questions.explanation: Automatic stabilizers work counter-cyclically. When GDP decreases (recession), they automatically decrease tax revenues (due to lower incomes) and increase transfers (e.g., unemployment benefits), which helps stabilize the economy without the need for conscious government action.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of an automatic stabilizer that helps control inflation?
options: An increase in income tax revenue collected
An increase in the reserve ratio
An increase in spending on unemployment payments
An increase in discretionary government spending
An increase in the money supply
questions.explanation: Automatic stabilizers help control inflation by automatically increasing tax revenues during economic expansion. When the economy grows and incomes rise, the progressive tax system automatically collects more taxes, reducing disposable income and helping control inflation without conscious government action.

unit-4.title: Financial sector
unit-4.description: Understanding money, banking, financial markets, and monetary policy

macroecon-u4-l1-article.title: Learn: Financial assets
importantPoints: Interest is the price paid for borrowing money
Bonds are debt instruments with fixed interest payments
Bond prices and interest rates move in opposite directions
Stocks represent ownership in companies
Bonds are lower risk; stocks are higher risk with higher potential returns

questions.question: If the interest rate on bonds increases, which of the following is the most likely result?
options: The quantity demanded of money increases
The supply of money decreases
Bond prices increase
The transaction costs associated with holding money will increase
People will be willing to hold less wealth in the form of money
questions.explanation: When the interest rate on bonds increases, the opportunity cost of holding money (the cost of forgone opportunities) also increases. People will want to hold less money and more bonds to earn higher interest. This decreases the demand for money.

questions.question: Daenerys bought government bonds with a face value of $1000 last year. At the time, she could have earned 6% interest if she had deposited money in a savings account at the Iron Bank. All of a sudden, interest rates at the Iron Bank increased to 9%. What will happen to the price of Daenerys's bonds?
options: The price of the bonds will increase
The price of the bonds will decrease
The price of bonds is unaffected by the interest rate
The price of the bond will become the price that makes the interest earned on both assets equal
The price of the bond will remain $1000
questions.explanation: When interest rates rise, new bonds offer higher interest. Existing bonds with lower rates become less attractive, so their prices fall to equalize their effective yield with new bonds. Bond prices and interest rates are inversely related.

questions.question: All else equal, which of the following financial assets carries the most risk?
options: Stocks
Savings deposits
Bonds
Checking deposits
Cash
questions.explanation: Stocks carry the most risk because their value can fluctuate significantly, and investors can lose their entire investment. Savings deposits, bonds, checking deposits, and cash are safer, with less risk of loss of value.

questions.question: Which of the following financial assets is the most liquid?
options: Gold
Bonds
Savings accounts
Money
Stocks
questions.explanation: Money (cash and checking deposits) is the most liquid asset because it can be immediately used for transactions without loss of value. Gold, bonds, savings accounts, and stocks require conversion to money before use in transactions, so they are less liquid.

macroecon-u4-l2-article.title: Learn: Nominal vs. real interest rates
importantPoints: Nominal return is the stated return; real return adjusts for inflation
Real return = Nominal return - Inflation rate
Real returns show actual purchasing power gained
Fisher equation: (1 + Nominal) = (1 + Real) × (1 + Inflation)
Indexing adjusts payments for inflation but has limitations

macroecon-u4-l2-quiz.title: Quiz: Nominal vs. real interest rates

questions.question: Hodor borrowed $1000. The bank charges him 5% interest per year. At the end of one year, he paid $50 in interest. During that year, there was a 2% increase in the GDP deflator. What was the nominal interest rate?
options: This cannot be determined without more information
questions.explanation: The nominal interest rate is the rate that the bank actually charges, without adjustment for inflation. In this case, the bank charges 5% per year, so the nominal interest rate is 5%. The inflation information (2%) is needed to calculate the real interest rate, but not to determine the nominal rate.

questions.question: Ygritte loaned Mans $100. Mans paid her back $110 one year later. The annual rate of inflation was 3%. What was the real interest rate that Ygritte earned on this loan?
questions.explanation: Nominal interest rate = ($110 - $100) / $100 = 10%. Real interest rate = Nominal rate - Inflation = 10% - 3% = 7%. The real interest rate shows the actual purchasing power of the interest earned.

questions.question: The Iron Bank wants to make sure that the purchasing power of the interest that they get paid on loans is at least 11%. Real GDP is increasing at 5% per year, and the expected rate of inflation is 7% per year. If all banks in Westeros want to earn the same real return as the Iron Bank, what is the nominal interest rate (n.i.r) in Westeros?
questions.explanation: Nominal interest rate = Real interest rate + Expected inflation. If banks want a real return of 11%, and expected inflation is 7%, then nominal interest rate = 11% + 7% = 18%.

questions.question: Which of the following best describes the difference between nominal interest rates and real interest rates?
options: nominal interest rates are not adjusted for inflation; real interest rates are adjusted for inflation
nominal interest rates are what banks charge; real interest is what borrowers pay
nominal interest is what you earn from a savings account; real interest is what the bank pays savings accounts
nominal interest is paid on bonds; real interest is paid on stocks
nominal interest is adjusted for inflation; real interest is what borrowers pay
questions.explanation: The nominal interest rate is the rate without adjustment for inflation - it's the actual rate you see. The real interest rate is the nominal rate adjusted for inflation, showing the actual purchasing power. Real rate = Nominal rate - Inflation.

lesson-4-3.title: Definition, measurement, and functions of money

macroecon-u4-l3-video-1.title: Definition, measurement, and functions of money

macroecon-u4-l3-article.title: Learn: Definition, measurement, and functions of money
importantPoints: Money supply measured as M0 (narrowest), M1, and M2 (broadest)
Money serves four functions: medium of exchange, unit of account, store of value, standard of deferred payment
Commodity money has intrinsic value; fiat money is government-backed
Hyperinflation destroys money's functions
Legal tender is currency that must be accepted for debts

macroecon-u4-l3-quiz.title: Quiz: Definition, measurement, and functions of money

lesson-4-4.title: Banking and the expansion of the money supply

macroecon-u4-l4-video-1.title: Banking and the expansion of the money supply

macroecon-u4-l4-article.title: Learn: Banking and the expansion of the money supply
importantPoints: Fractional reserve banking allows banks to lend most deposits
Banks create money through the lending process
Money multiplier = 1 / Reserve requirement
Fractional reserve banking has risks but enables credit creation
Full reserve banking prevents money creation but eliminates bank run risk

macroecon-u4-l4-quiz.title: Quiz: Banking and the expansion of the money supply

questions.question: Required reserves are best described by which of the following statements?
options: the amount a bank has to pay for an overnight loan from another bank
the money owed to a bank's owners
the money that a bank can loan out
the proportion of checkable deposits that a bank must keep on hand
the proportion of the total assets the bank holds as bonds
questions.explanation: Required reserves are the minimum proportion of checkable deposits that a bank must keep in reserve (in its vault or at the central bank) as required by the central bank. They cannot be loaned out.

questions.question: When Hodor deposited $1000 in the bank, the bank kept $200 in its vault and loaned out $800. Which of the following best describes what the bank is doing?
options: Investment banking
Full reserve banking
Excess reserve banking
Required reserve banking
Fractional reserve banking
questions.explanation: Fractional reserve banking is a system where banks keep only a fraction of deposits as reserves (in this case 20%) and loan out the rest (80%). This allows banks to create money through lending.

questions.question: Banks in Westeros have been required to keep 10% of all checkable deposits on reserve, but now the central bank has changed the reserve requirement to 20%. What immediate effect does this have on banks' balance sheets?
options: Excess reserves increase
Liabilities increase
Required reserves decrease
Liabilities decrease
Excess reserves decrease
questions.explanation: When the reserve requirement increases from 10% to 20%, banks must keep a larger proportion of deposits as reserves. This means that some of their excess reserves (reserves above the requirement) now become required reserves, so excess reserves decrease.

questions.question: Milton deposits $100,000 in the First Bank of the Shire. Which of the following best describes the initial impact this deposit will have on the bank's balance sheet?
options: Assets will increase; liabilities will not change
Assets will not change; liabilities will increase
Assets will increase; liabilities will increase
Assets will decrease; liabilities will increase
Assets will increase; liabilities will decrease
questions.explanation: When a customer deposits money in a bank, the bank receives cash (an asset) and simultaneously has a liability to the depositor (a liability). The deposit increases both the bank's assets (cash in vault) and liabilities (customer deposits).

macroecon-u4-l5-article.title: Learn: The money market
importantPoints: Demand for money is downward sloping (inverse relationship with interest rates)
Money market equilibrium determines the interest rate
Money supply increase lowers interest rates
Money demand increase raises interest rates
The money market connects monetary policy to interest rates

macroecon-u4-l6-article.title: Learn: Monetary policy
importantPoints: Monetary policy is conducted by the central bank
Main tools: open market operations, reserve requirements, discount rate
Expansionary policy increases money supply to fight recessions
Contractionary policy decreases money supply to fight inflation
Monetary policy affects interest rates, which affect investment and AD

macroecon-u4-l7-article.title: Learn: The market for loanable funds
importantPoints: Loanable funds market shows supply (saving) and demand (investment)
Equilibrium determines interest rate and quantity of funds
National saving = Private saving + Public saving
In equilibrium, National saving = Investment
Changes in saving or investment shift the curves

macroecon-u4-l7-quiz.title: Quiz: The market for loanable funds

lesson-4-8.title: Interest rates and the time value of money

macroecon-u4-l8-video-1.title: Interest rates and the time value of money

macroecon-u4-l8-article.title: Learn: Interest rates and the time value of money
importantPoints: Present value is the current worth of future money
Money today is worth more than money tomorrow
PV = FV / (1 + r)^n
Present value is used for bond pricing and investment decisions
Higher interest rates reduce present value

macroecon-u4-l8-quiz.title: Quiz: Interest rates and the time value of money

unit-5.title: Long-run consequences of stabilization policies
unit-5.description: Understanding long-run effects of fiscal and monetary policy, growth, and debt

lesson-5-1.title: Fiscal and Monetary Policy Actions in the Short Run

macroecon-u5-l1-video-1.title: Fiscal and Monetary Policy Actions in the Short Run

macroecon-u5-l1-article.title: Learn: Fiscal and Monetary Policy Actions in the Short Run
importantPoints: Fiscal and monetary policy can be coordinated or conflict
Coordinated policies are more effective
Both affect aggregate demand in the short run
Fiscal policy has direct effects; monetary policy works through interest rates
Policy coordination requires communication between institutions

macroecon-u5-l1-quiz.title: Quiz: Fiscal and Monetary Policy Actions

macroecon-u5-l2-article.title: Learn: The Phillips Curve
importantPoints: Short-run Phillips Curve shows trade-off between inflation and unemployment
Long-run Phillips Curve is vertical at natural unemployment rate
AD changes cause movement along SRPC
Supply shocks shift SRPC
No long-run trade-off between inflation and unemployment

macroecon-u5-l3-article.title: Learn: Money Growth and Inflation
importantPoints: Quantity theory: M × V = P × Y
Money supply growth causes inflation if V and Y are constant
Velocity changes can drive prices independently
Deflation can occur if velocity falls or output grows faster than money
Moderate inflation (2-3%) is normal in healthy economies

macroecon-u5-l4-article.title: Learn: Crowding Out
importantPoints: Crowding out occurs when government spending reduces private spending
Mechanism: Government borrowing → Higher interest rates → Less investment
More likely near full employment with fixed money supply
Can be complete, partial, or absent
Monetary accommodation can reduce crowding out

macroecon-u5-l5-article.title: Learn: Deficits and Debts
importantPoints: Deficit is annual (flow); debt is accumulated (stock)
Deficits can stimulate economy but create debt
Debt-to-GDP ratio measures debt burden
Long-run concerns include debt service and reduced flexibility
Sustainable debt requires GDP growth to outpace debt growth

macroecon-u5-l6-article.title: Learn: Economic Growth
importantPoints: Economic growth is the increase in real GDP over time
Growth comes from resources, technology, and productivity
Long-run growth (trend) differs from short-run fluctuations
Growth improves living standards
Sustainable growth balances economic, environmental, and social factors

unit-6.title: Open economy: international trade and finance
unit-6.description: Understanding balance of payments, exchange rates, and international capital flows

macroecon-u6-l1-article.title: Learn: The balance of payments
importantPoints: Balance of payments records all international transactions
Current account = trade + income + transfers
Capital account = investment flows
Current account + Capital account = 0 (must balance)
Trade deficit must be financed by capital inflows

macroecon-u6-l2-article.title: Learn: Exchange rates
importantPoints: Exchange rate is the price of one currency in terms of another
Appreciation = currency becomes more valuable
Depreciation = currency becomes less valuable
Supply and demand determine floating exchange rates
Real exchange rate adjusts for price levels

macroecon-u6-l3-article.title: Learn: The foreign exchange market
importantPoints: Forex market is where currencies are traded
Supply and demand determine exchange rates
Central banks use reserves to influence rates
Speculative attacks can force devaluation
Fixed rates require sufficient reserves and credibility

lesson-6-4.title: Effect of changes in policies and economic conditions on the foreign exchange market

macroecon-u6-l4-video-1.title: Effect of changes in policies and economic conditions on the foreign exchange market

macroecon-u6-l4-article.title: Learn: Effect of changes in policies and economic conditions on the foreign exchange market
importantPoints: Many factors shift currency supply and demand
Higher interest rates → Currency appreciation
Higher imports → Currency depreciation
Monetary policy affects exchange rates through interest rates
Fiscal policy has mixed effects depending on relative magnitudes

macroecon-u6-l4-quiz.title: Quiz: Effect of changes in policies and economic conditions on the foreign exchange market

lesson-6-5.title: Real interest rates and international capital flows

macroecon-u6-l5-video-1.title: Real interest rates and international capital flows

macroecon-u6-l5-article.title: Learn: Changes in the foreign exchange markets and net exports
importantPoints: Real interest rate differentials drive capital flows
Higher real rates → Capital inflows → Currency appreciation
Currency appreciation → Lower net exports
Currency depreciation → Higher net exports
Impossible trinity: can't have fixed rate, independent monetary policy, and free capital flows

macroecon-u6-l5-quiz.title: Quiz: Real interest rates and international capital flows

unit-7.title: Keynesian approaches and IS-LM
unit-7.description: Understanding consumption functions, Keynesian cross, IS-LM model, and Keynesian economics

macroecon-u7-l1-article.title: Learn: The consumption function
importantPoints: Consumption function: C = C₀ + MPC × Yd
MPC is the fraction of additional income consumed
Consumption increases with income but by less than income
Taxes reduce disposable income and thus consumption
With proportional taxes, MPC out of total income is lower

macroecon-u7-l2-article.title: Learn: The Keynesian cross
importantPoints: Equilibrium: Planned aggregate expenditure = Output
45-degree line shows all points where AE = Y
AE curve shifts with changes in autonomous spending
Multiplier = 1 / (1 - MPC)
Economy adjusts through inventory changes

macroecon-u7-l3-article.title: Learn: IS-LM
importantPoints: IS curve: Goods market equilibrium (investment = saving)
LM curve: Money market equilibrium (money supply = money demand)
IS slopes down: Higher interest rates → Lower output
LM slopes up: Higher output → Higher interest rates
IS-LM intersection determines both output and interest rate

macroecon-u7-l4-article.title: Learn: Keynesian economics and its critiques
importantPoints: Keynesian economics emphasizes demand and short-run fluctuations
Government intervention can stabilize the economy
Risks include inflation, crowding out, and deficits
Keynes' Law: Demand creates supply (vs. Say's Law: Supply creates demand)
Keynesian view: Markets may not self-adjust, government intervention needed

unit-8.title: Contemporary macroeconomic issues
unit-8.description: Understanding income inequality, wealth distribution, and the 2008 financial crisis

lesson-8-1.title: Analysis of income inequality in the United States (in partnership with The New York Times)

macroecon-u8-l1-video-1.title: Analysis of income inequality in the United States

macroecon-u8-l1-article.title: Learn: Analysis of income inequality in the United States
importantPoints: Income inequality in US has increased dramatically since 1980
Top 1% captured large share of income growth
Middle class income stagnated
US has higher inequality than most peer countries
Tax policy changes reduced progressivity

macroecon-u8-l2-article.title: Learn: National income and inequality
importantPoints: Wealth (stock) differs from income (flow)
Piketty's thesis: r > g leads to increasing inequality
Capital ownership is highly concentrated
Education can reduce inequality through human capital
Historical data shows r typically exceeds g

macroecon-u8-l3-article.title: Learn: The 2008 Financial Crisis
importantPoints: Crisis caused by housing bubble, subprime lending, excessive leverage
Distinction between liquidity and solvency problems
Book value vs. market value created illusion of solvency
Systemic risk required government intervention
TARP injected capital, but created moral hazard

microeconomics.title: Microeconomics
microeconomics.description: Study of individual economic units and their decision-making processes

unit-1.title: Basic economic concepts
unit-1.description: Introduction to economics, scarcity, economic systems, and the circular flow model

micro-u1-l1-article.title: Learn: Introduction to economics
importantPoints: Economics studies allocation of scarce resources
Scarcity forces choices and creates opportunity costs
Four factors of production: land, labor, capital, entrepreneurship
Economic models simplify reality to aid understanding
Positive statements are factual; normative statements are value judgments

micro-u1-l2-article.title: Learn: Economic systems
importantPoints: Property rights are essential for market systems
Markets coordinate economic activity through prices
Incentives (self-interest, profits) drive market behavior
Circular flow model shows resource and money flows
Economic systems differ in how they allocate resources

unit-2.title: Supply, demand, and market equilibrium
unit-2.description: Understanding demand, supply, market equilibrium, and how markets adjust to changes

micro-u2-l1-article.title: Learn: Demand
importantPoints: Law of demand: Price and quantity demanded are inversely related
Market demand is the sum of all individual demands
Substitution and income effects explain downward-sloping demand
Factors that shift demand: income, related goods, tastes, population, expectations
Normal goods: demand increases with income; inferior goods: demand decreases

micro-u2-l2-article.title: Learn: Supply
importantPoints: Law of supply: Price and quantity supplied are directly related
Supply curves slope upward due to profit incentives
Factors that shift supply: input prices, technology, number of sellers, expectations, policies
Change in supply = shift of curve; change in quantity supplied = movement along curve

lesson-2-3.title: Market equilibrium and changes in equilibrium

micro-u2-l3-video-1.title: Market equilibrium and changes in equilibrium

micro-u2-l3-article.title: Learn: Market equilibrium and changes in equilibrium
importantPoints: Equilibrium: quantity demanded = quantity supplied
Shortage: Qd > Qs (price below equilibrium)
Surplus: Qs > Qd (price above equilibrium)
Demand increase → Higher price and quantity
Supply increase → Lower price, higher quantity

micro-u2-l3-quiz.title: Quiz: Market equilibrium and changes in equilibrium

unit-3.title: Elasticity
unit-3.description: Understanding price elasticity of demand and supply, income elasticity, and cross-price elasticity

micro-u3-l1-article.title: Learn: Price Elasticity of Demand
importantPoints: Price elasticity measures responsiveness of quantity to price changes
Elastic (|Ed| > 1): quantity changes more than price
Inelastic (|Ed| < 1): quantity changes less than price
Determinants: substitutes, necessity, income proportion, time, market definition
Elasticity affects total revenue: elastic → price and TR move opposite, inelastic → price and TR move together

micro-u3-l2-article.title: Learn: Price Elasticity of Supply
importantPoints: Price elasticity of supply measures responsiveness of quantity supplied to price
Determinants: production flexibility, time horizon, input availability, storage, capacity
Short run: more inelastic (fixed capacity)
Long run: more elastic (can adjust all inputs)
Supply elasticity helps predict how markets adjust to changes

lesson-3-3.title: Income Elasticity of Demand and Cross-Price Elasticity of Demand

micro-u3-l3-video-1.title: Income Elasticity of Demand and Cross-Price Elasticity of Demand

micro-u3-l3-article.title: Learn: Income Elasticity of Demand and Cross-Price Elasticity of Demand
importantPoints: Income elasticity: measures how demand responds to income changes
Normal goods: Ei > 0; inferior goods: Ei < 0
Luxury goods: Ei > 1; necessities: 0 < Ei < 1
Cross-price elasticity: measures relationship between goods
Substitutes: Ec > 0; complements: Ec < 0

micro-u3-l3-quiz.title: Quiz: Income Elasticity of Demand and Cross-Price Elasticity of Demand

unit-4.title: Consumer and producer surplus, market interventions, and international trade
unit-4.description: Understanding consumer and producer surplus, market interventions, deadweight loss, and international trade

micro-u4-l1-article.title: Learn: Consumer and Producer Surplus
importantPoints: Demand curve represents marginal benefit
Consumer surplus = willingness to pay - price paid
Producer surplus = price - marginal cost
Total surplus = consumer surplus + producer surplus
Competitive equilibrium maximizes total surplus (allocative efficiency)

micro-u4-l2-article.title: Learn: Market Interventions and Deadweight Loss
importantPoints: Price controls create deadweight loss by preventing equilibrium
Taxes create deadweight loss and redistribute surplus
Tax incidence depends on elasticities: more inelastic side bears more burden
Deadweight loss increases with tax size and elasticities
Market interventions reduce economic efficiency

micro-u4-l2-quiz.title: Quiz: Market Interventions and Deadweight Loss

micro-u4-l3-article.title: Learn: International Trade
importantPoints: Trade increases total surplus (gains from trade)
Trade creates winners (consumers in import case, producers in export case) and losers
Tariffs protect domestic producers but harm consumers
Tariffs create deadweight loss (production and consumption inefficiency)
Trade analysis requires comparing surpluses with and without trade

unit-5.title: Consumer theory
unit-5.description: Understanding utility, marginal utility, utility maximization, and consumer choice with indifference curves

lesson-5-1.title: Introduction to consumer theory; total utility and marginal utility

micro-u5-l1-video-1.title: Introduction to consumer theory; total utility and marginal utility

micro-u5-l1-article.title: Learn: Introduction to consumer theory; total utility and marginal utility
importantPoints: Total utility increases with quantity but at decreasing rate
Marginal utility decreases with quantity (law of diminishing MU)
Utility maximization: MU/P equal for all goods
Demand curve can be derived from utility maximization
Consumers adjust consumption to equalize marginal utility per dollar

micro-u5-l1-quiz.title: Quiz: Introduction to consumer theory; total utility and marginal utility

lesson-5-2.title: Utility maximization using marginal utility per dollar spent

micro-u5-l2-video-1.title: Utility maximization using marginal utility per dollar spent

micro-u5-l2-article.title: Learn: Utility maximization using marginal utility per dollar spent
importantPoints: Utility maximization: MU/P equal for all goods
Must satisfy budget constraint
Rank options by MU/P and allocate budget accordingly
Continue until budget exhausted and MU/P equalized
This method guarantees maximum utility given budget

micro-u5-l2-quiz.title: Quiz: Utility maximization using marginal utility per dollar spent

micro-u5-l3-article.title: Learn: Utility maximization with indifference curves
importantPoints: Budget line shows affordable combinations given prices and income
Indifference curves show combinations giving same utility
Optimal point: tangency of budget line and indifference curve
At optimum: MRS = price ratio (MUₐ/MUᵦ = Pₐ/Pᵦ)
Different preferences lead to different indifference curve shapes

unit-6.title: Production decisions and economic profit
unit-6.description: Understanding production functions, costs, profit maximization, and firm entry/exit decisions

micro-u6-l1-article.title: Learn: Introduction to production and costs
importantPoints: Production function shows relationship between inputs and output
Total product: total output; Marginal product: additional output per input
Average product: output per unit of input
Law of diminishing returns: MP eventually decreases
MP and AP relationships determine optimal input levels

micro-u6-l1-quiz.title: Quiz: Introduction to production and costs

lesson-6-2.title: Production and costs in the short run

micro-u6-l2-video-1.title: Production and costs in the short run

micro-u6-l2-article.title: Learn: Production and costs in the short run
importantPoints: Fixed costs don't vary with output; variable costs do
MC is slope of TC curve; intersects AVC and ATC at minimums
Profit maximization: MR = MC
Shut-down rule: produce if P > AVC
Fixed cost changes affect ATC; variable cost changes affect all costs

micro-u6-l2-quiz.title: Quiz: Production and costs in the short run

lesson-6-3.title: Production and costs in the long run

micro-u6-l3-video-1.title: Production and costs in the long run

micro-u6-l3-article.title: Learn: Production and costs in the long run
importantPoints: Long run: all inputs variable, no fixed costs
LRATC is envelope of short-run ATC curves
Economies of scale: decreasing LRATC
Diseconomies of scale: increasing LRATC
Minimum efficient scale affects market structure

micro-u6-l3-quiz.title: Quiz: Production and costs in the long run

micro-u6-l4-article.title: Learn: Types of profit
importantPoints: Accounting profit = Revenue - Explicit costs
Economic profit = Revenue - Total opportunity cost
Implicit costs are opportunity costs of own resources
Economic profit accounts for all opportunity costs
Long-run competitive equilibrium: economic profit = 0

micro-u6-l5-article.title: Learn: Profit maximization
importantPoints: Profit maximization: MR = MC
If MR > MC, produce more; if MR < MC, produce less
Profit = (P - ATC) × Q or TR - TC
Systematic approach: find MR, MC, set equal, find Q and P

lesson-6-6.title: Firm entry, exit, and the shut-down rule

micro-u6-l6-video-1.title: Firm entry, exit, and the shut-down rule

micro-u6-l6-article.title: Learn: Firm entry, exit, and the shut-down rule
importantPoints: Short-run shut-down: P < AVC
Long-run exit: P < ATC
Long-run competitive equilibrium: economic profit = 0
Entry/exit drives profit to zero
Industry cost structure affects long-run supply curve

micro-u6-l6-quiz.title: Quiz: Firm entry, exit, and the shut-down rule

unit-7.title: Forms of competition
unit-7.description: Understanding perfect competition, monopoly, monopolistic competition, oligopoly, and game theory

micro-u7-l1-article.title: Learn: Perfect competition
importantPoints: Perfect competition: many buyers/sellers, identical products, free entry/exit
Firms are price takers: P = MR = MC
Long-run equilibrium: economic profit = 0, P = ATC (minimum)
Perfect competition achieves allocative and productive efficiency
Long-run supply depends on industry cost structure

micro-u7-l2-article.title: Learn: Monopoly
importantPoints: Monopoly: one seller, barriers to entry
MR < P in monopoly (unlike perfect competition)
Profit maximization: MR = MC, but P > MC
Monopoly creates deadweight loss
Monopoly can earn economic profit in long run

micro-u7-l3-article.title: Learn: Price discrimination
importantPoints: Price discrimination: different prices for same product
Requires: market power, different elasticities, no arbitrage
Increases profit by capturing consumer surplus
May increase output and reduce deadweight loss
Perfect discrimination: no deadweight loss, all surplus to producer

micro-u7-l4-article.title: Learn: Monopolistic competition
importantPoints: Monopolistic competition: many firms, differentiated products
Short run: can earn economic profit
Long run: economic profit = 0, but P > MC
Inefficient but provides product variety
Entry/exit drives profit to zero

micro-u7-l5-article.title: Learn: Oligopoly and game theory
importantPoints: Oligopoly: few firms, strategic interdependence
Prisoners' dilemma: incentive to cheat even when cooperation is better
Nash equilibrium: no player wants to deviate
Cartels are unstable due to incentive to cheat
Game theory analyzes strategic interactions

unit-8.title: Factor markets
unit-8.description: Understanding factor markets, labor demand and supply, cost minimization, and monopsony

micro-u8-l1-article.title: Learn: Introduction to factor markets
importantPoints: Marginal revenue product (MRP) = MR × MP
Profit maximization: hire until MRP = wage
Labor demand is derived from output demand
Labor supply depends on labor-leisure tradeoff
Income and substitution effects determine labor supply shape

lesson-8-2.title: Changes in factor demand and supply

micro-u8-l2-video-1.title: Changes in factor demand and supply

micro-u8-l2-article.title: Learn: Changes in factor demand and supply
importantPoints: Market demand is sum of individual firm demands
Labor supply shifts: population, preferences, non-wage income, opportunities
Labor demand shifts: output price, technology, other input prices, number of firms
Changes in supply and demand affect wages and employment

micro-u8-l2-quiz.title: Quiz: Changes in factor demand and supply

lesson-8-3.title: Optimal choice of factors in perfectly competitive factor markets

micro-u8-l3-video-1.title: Optimal choice of factors in perfectly competitive factor markets

micro-u8-l3-article.title: Learn: Optimal choice of factors in perfectly competitive factor markets
importantPoints: Cost minimization: MP/W equal for all inputs
Profit maximization: MRP = input price
Firms choose input combination to minimize cost and maximize profit
Equalizing MP per dollar ensures efficient input use

micro-u8-l3-quiz.title: Quiz: Optimal choice of factors in perfectly competitive factor markets

lesson-8-4.title: Choosing inputs when factor markets are monopsonistically competitive

micro-u8-l4-video-1.title: Choosing inputs when factor markets are monopsonistically competitive

micro-u8-l4-article.title: Learn: Choosing inputs when factor markets are monopsonistically competitive
importantPoints: Monopsony: one buyer in factor market
MFC > Wage (must raise wage for all workers)
Profit maximization: MRP = MFC
Monopsony pays less and hires less than competitive market
Minimum wage may increase employment in monopsony

micro-u8-l4-quiz.title: Quiz: Choosing inputs when factor markets are monopsonistically competitive

unit-9.title: Market failure and the role of government
unit-9.description: Understanding externalities, public goods, common resources, and government intervention

micro-u9-l1-article.title: Learn: Externalities
importantPoints: Negative externalities: overproduction, MSC > MPC
Positive externalities: underproduction, MSB > MPB
Pigouvian taxes can correct negative externalities
Pollution is a negative externality requiring policy intervention
Innovation is a positive externality requiring support

lesson-9-2.title: The four types of goods: private goods, public goods, common resources, and natural monopolies

micro-u9-l2-video-1.title: The four types of goods: private goods, public goods, common resources, and natural monopolies

micro-u9-l2-article.title: Learn: The four types of goods: private goods, public goods, common resources, and natural monopolies
importantPoints: Rival: one person's use prevents another's
Excludable: can prevent use
Public goods: non-rival and non-excludable
Free-rider problem prevents private provision
Common resources: rival but non-excludable (tragedy of commons)

finance-markets.title: Finance & Markets
finance-markets.description: Comprehensive study of financial markets, instruments, and investment strategies

unit-1.title: Interest and debt
unit-1.description: Understanding interest, compound interest, credit cards, loans, present value, and bankruptcy

finance-u1-l1-article.title: Learn: Compound interest basics
importantPoints: Compound interest: interest on principal + accumulated interest
Formula: A = P(1 + r)^n
Rule of 72: approximate years to double = 72 / interest rate
Compound interest grows faster than simple interest

finance-u1-l2-article.title: Learn: Interest basics
importantPoints: Interest: price for borrowing or return for lending
Compound interest: interest on principal + accumulated interest
More frequent compounding = higher returns
Formula: A = P(1 + r/n)^(nt)

finance-u1-l3-article.title: Learn: Credit cards and loans
importantPoints: APR: stated annual interest rate
Effective APR: actual rate after compounding
Credit card system involves multiple institutions
Payday loans: very high interest, should be avoided

finance-u1-l4-article.title: Learn: Continuous compound interest and e
importantPoints: e (Euler's number) ≈ 2.71828
e = limit of (1 + 1/n)^n as n → ∞
Continuous compounding: A = Pe^(rt)
Continuous compounding gives maximum growth

finance-u1-l5-article.title: Learn: Present value
importantPoints: Time value of money: money today worth more than future
Present value: current worth of future sum
PV = FV / (1 + r)^n
DCF: discounts all future cash flows to present

finance-u1-l6-article.title: Learn: Personal bankruptcy
importantPoints: Bankruptcy: legal process for debt relief
Chapter 7: liquidation, quick discharge
Chapter 13: reorganization, repayment plan
Serious consequences: credit damage, long-term effects

unit-2.title: Housing
unit-2.description: Understanding home equity, balance sheets, renting vs. buying, mortgages, and the home buying process

lesson-2-1.title: Home equity and personal balance sheets

finance-u2-l1-video-1.title: Home equity and personal balance sheets

finance-u2-l1-article.title: Learn: Home equity and personal balance sheets
importantPoints: Balance sheet: Assets = Liabilities + Equity
Home equity = Home value - Mortgage balance
Equity grows through appreciation and principal payments
Home equity loans use home as collateral

finance-u2-l2-article.title: Learn: Renting vs. buying a home
importantPoints: Renting: flexibility, no maintenance, lower upfront costs
Buying: builds equity, tax benefits, stability
Buying not always better: consider transaction costs, maintenance, opportunity cost
Housing depreciation can create negative equity
Detailed analysis requires comparing all costs

finance-u2-l3-article.title: Learn: Mortgages
importantPoints: Mortgage: loan secured by real estate
Fixed-rate: constant rate, predictable
ARM: rate changes, lower initial rate but risky
Short sale: sell for less than mortgage balance
Mortgage payments calculated using geometric series

finance-u2-l4-article.title: Learn: Home buying process
importantPoints: Title: legal ownership; Deed: document transferring title
Title insurance protects against ownership claims
Making offer: research, negotiate, include contingencies
Escrow: neutral third party holds funds/documents
Mortgage escrow: holds tax/insurance payments

unit-3.title: Inflation
unit-3.description: Understanding inflation, deflation, real vs. nominal returns, and capacity utilization

finance-u3-l1-article.title: Learn: Inflation basics
importantPoints: Inflation: general increase in prices over time
Reduces purchasing power of money
Measured as percentage change in price index
CPI: primary measure of consumer inflation

finance-u3-l2-article.title: Learn: Inflation scenarios
importantPoints: Moderate inflation (2-3%): normal in healthy economies
Stagflation: high inflation + high unemployment + low growth
Hyperinflation: extremely rapid inflation (>50% per month)
Each scenario has different causes and consequences

finance-u3-l3-article.title: Learn: Real and nominal return
importantPoints: Nominal return: return without inflation adjustment
Real return: return adjusted for inflation
Real Return ≈ Nominal Return - Inflation
Real return shows actual purchasing power

finance-u3-l4-article.title: Learn: Capacity utilization and inflation
importantPoints: Capacity utilization: percentage of capacity used
Low utilization: can increase production, prices stable
High utilization: hard to increase, prices may rise
Capacity utilization affects inflation/deflation pressures

finance-u3-l5-article.title: Learn: Deflation
importantPoints: Deflation: general decrease in prices
Can occur despite money growth if velocity falls
Deflationary spiral: self-reinforcing cycle
Dangerous: increases real debt, encourages hoarding

unit-4.title: Taxes
unit-4.description: Understanding personal taxes, corporate taxation, and tax planning

finance-u4-l1-article.title: Learn: Personal taxes
importantPoints: Progressive taxation: higher income → higher rate
Tax deductions reduce taxable income
AMT ensures high earners pay minimum tax
Estate tax applies only to very large estates
Marriage penalty: married couples may pay more

finance-u4-l2-article.title: Learn: Corporate taxation
importantPoints: Corporations: separate legal entity with limited liability
Double taxation: corporate tax + personal tax on dividends
Transfer pricing: can shift profits to low-tax countries
Tax havens: countries with very low taxes
Raises fairness and efficiency questions

unit-5.title: Accounting and financial statements
unit-5.description: Understanding cash vs. accrual accounting, financial statements, and depreciation

finance-u5-l1-article.title: Learn: Cash versus accrual accounting
importantPoints: Cash accounting: records when cash received/paid
Accrual accounting: records when earned/incurred
Accrual matches revenue with expenses
Accrual required for large businesses (GAAP)

finance-u5-l2-article.title: Learn: Three core financial statements
importantPoints: Balance sheet: snapshot at point in time
Income statement: performance over period
Cash flow statement: actual cash movements
Net income flows to retained earnings on balance sheet
Fair value: current market price vs. historical cost

finance-u5-l3-article.title: Learn: Depreciation and amortization
importantPoints: Depreciation: allocates cost of tangible assets over useful life
Amortization: allocates cost of intangible assets over useful life
Both are non-cash expenses
Must be added back in cash flow statement
Smooths expenses and matches with revenue

unit-6.title: Stocks and bonds
unit-6.description: Understanding stocks, bonds, corporate finance, valuation, and company life cycle

finance-u6-l1-article.title: Learn: Introduction to stocks
importantPoints: Stock: ownership share in company
Shareholders have voting and dividend rights
Stocks: higher risk, higher potential return
Bonds: lower risk, fixed return

finance-u6-l2-article.title: Learn: Shorting stock
importantPoints: Short selling: sell stock you don't own, bet on price decline
Unlimited loss potential (price can rise indefinitely)
Requires margin account and collateral
Controversial but serves market functions

lesson-6-3.title: Understanding company statements and capital structure

finance-u6-l3-video-1.title: Understanding company statements and capital structure

finance-u6-l3-article.title: Learn: Understanding company statements and capital structure
importantPoints: Gross profit = Revenue - COGS
Operating profit = Gross profit - Operating expenses
Capital structure: mix of debt and equity
Market cap = Share price × Shares outstanding

finance-u6-l4-article.title: Learn: Corporate metrics and valuation
importantPoints: EPS = Net income / Shares outstanding
P/E = Price / EPS (shows valuation)
ROA = Net income / Assets (measures efficiency)
Enterprise value = Market cap + Debt - Cash
EBITDA: operating performance before financing/accounting effects

lesson-6-5.title: Life of a company – from birth to death

finance-u6-l5-video-1.title: Life of a company – from birth to death

finance-u6-l5-article.title: Learn: Life of a company – from birth to death
importantPoints: Startup funding: bootstrapping → angels → VC → IPO
IPO: transition from private to public
Equity: dilutes ownership, no repayment
Debt: must repay, keeps ownership
Chapter 7: liquidation; Chapter 11: restructuring

finance-u6-l6-article.title: Learn: Dilution
importantPoints: Dilution: reduction in ownership percentage
Occurs when new shares issued
Ownership % decreases but company value may increase

finance-u6-l7-article.title: Learn: Mergers and acquisitions
importantPoints: Stock acquisitions: use shares instead of cash
Target stock usually rises after announcement
Acquirer stock may fall
Merger arbitrage: profit from acquisition spreads

finance-u6-l8-article.title: Learn: Leveraged buy-outs
importantPoints: LBO: buying company with mostly debt
High leverage amplifies returns and risk
Uses company assets as collateral
Tax benefits from interest deduction

finance-u6-l9-article.title: Learn: Bonds
importantPoints: Bonds: loans with fixed payments and maturity
Bond prices inversely related to interest rates
Yield curve: shows yields at different maturities
Normal curve: upward sloping; Inverted: downward (recession signal)
Treasury bonds: safest, used as benchmark

finance-u6-l10-article.title: Learn: Corporate bankruptcy
importantPoints: Chapter 7: liquidation, company ends
Chapter 11: restructuring, company continues
Priority: secured creditors → unsecured → stockholders
Chapter 11 allows company to survive

unit-7.title: Investment vehicles, insurance, and retirement
unit-7.description: Understanding mutual funds, ETFs, retirement accounts, insurance, hedge funds, and investment principles

finance-u7-l1-article.title: Learn: Mutual funds and ETFs
