importantPoints: Open-ended funds: continuously create/redeem shares
Closed-end funds: fixed shares, trade on exchange
ETFs: trade like stocks, low fees, tax efficient
Ponzi schemes: fraudulent, use new money to pay old investors

finance-u7-l2-article.title: Learn: Retirement accounts: IRAs and 401ks
importantPoints: Traditional IRA: tax deduction now, taxes later
Roth IRA: taxes now, tax-free withdrawals
401(k): employer-sponsored, higher limits, employer match
Each has different tax treatment and benefits

finance-u7-l3-article.title: Learn: Life insurance
importantPoints: Term life: coverage for specific period
Pays benefit if death during term
Premiums based on death probability
No cash value, lower cost than permanent

finance-u7-l4-article.title: Learn: Hedge funds
importantPoints: Hedge funds: private, less regulated, for wealthy investors
Fee structure: management fee + performance fee (2 and 20)
Strategies: long-short, merger arbitrage, market neutral
Different from VC and private equity

finance-u7-l5-article.title: Learn: Investment and consumption
importantPoints: Risk-return tradeoff: higher risk → higher return
Human capital: ability to earn income
Investment vs. consumption: balance future and present
Wealth destruction: many factors can reduce wealth

unit-8.title: Money, banking and central banks
unit-8.description: Understanding banking, money creation, central banks, quantitative easing, financial crises, and cryptocurrencies

finance-u8-l1-article.title: Learn: Banking and money
importantPoints: Fractional reserve banking: banks hold fraction of deposits
Money multiplier: 1 / reserve ratio
Banks create money through lending
Central banks control money supply through various tools
Fed funds rate: key monetary policy tool

finance-u8-l2-article.title: Learn: Quantitative easing
importantPoints: QE: large-scale purchase of long-term securities
Used when interest rates near zero
Lowers long-term rates, stimulates economy
Risks: inflation, asset bubbles

finance-u8-l3-article.title: Learn: 2008 bank bailout
importantPoints: Liquidity vs. solvency: different problems need different solutions
Book value vs. market value: gap hid true condition
Systemic risk: justified government intervention
TARP: capital injections to stabilize banks
Moral hazard: bailouts create future risk-taking

finance-u8-l4-article.title: Learn: Geithner plan
importantPoints: Geithner plan: public-private partnership
Goal: remove toxic assets
Faced challenges in implementation
Part of comprehensive response

finance-u8-l5-article.title: Learn: Foreign exchange and trade
importantPoints: Exchange rates affect trade competitiveness
Currency pegs can influence trade
China-US debt loop: trade and capital flows
Carry trade: interest rate arbitrage with currency risk

finance-u8-l6-article.title: Learn: Chinese currency and U.S. debt
importantPoints: China pegged yuan to maintain trade advantage
Accumulated large foreign reserves
Financed US deficit through Treasury purchases
Floating exchange would reduce imbalances

finance-u8-l7-article.title: Learn: 2011-2012 Greek debt crisis
importantPoints: Greek crisis: high debt, recession, austerity
Bailouts came with strict conditions
Grexit considered but very disruptive
Contagion risk worried Europe

finance-u8-l8-article.title: Learn: Bitcoin
importantPoints: Bitcoin: decentralized digital currency
Blockchain: public ledger of transactions
Proof of work: secures network through computation
Limited supply: 21 million bitcoins
Cryptographic security: hashing and digital signatures

unit-9.title: Options, swaps, futures, MBSs, CDOs, and other derivatives
unit-9.description: Understanding options, futures, swaps, mortgage-backed securities, CDOs, credit default swaps, and option pricing

finance-u9-l1-article.title: Learn: Put and call options
importantPoints: Call: right to buy, put: right to sell
Options provide leverage
Puts can act as insurance
Put-call parity links option prices
Writing options: limited profit, large loss potential

finance-u9-l2-article.title: Learn: Forward and futures contracts
importantPoints: Forward: customized OTC contract
Futures: standardized exchange-traded
Margin: collateral, daily settlement
Contango: future > spot
Backwardation: future < spot
Arbitrage keeps prices aligned

finance-u9-l3-article.title: Learn: Mortgage-backed securities
importantPoints: MBS: securities backed by mortgage pools
Tranches: different risk/return classes
Risks: prepayment, default, interest rate

finance-u9-l4-article.title: Learn: Collateralized debt obligations
importantPoints: CDO: backed by pool of debt
Tranches: equity, mezzanine, senior
Risks: default, correlation, complexity
Played role in 2008 crisis

finance-u9-l5-article.title: Learn: Credit default swaps
importantPoints: CDS: insurance against default
Buyer pays premium, seller pays if default
Uses: hedging, speculation, arbitrage
Systemic risk: can amplify crises

finance-u9-l6-article.title: Learn: Interest rate swaps
importantPoints: Swap: exchange fixed for floating rate
Exchange interest payments, not principal
Uses: convert exposure, hedge, speculate
Risks: counterparty, basis, market

finance-u9-l7-article.title: Learn: Black-Scholes formula
importantPoints: Black-Scholes: model for option pricing
Inputs: price, strike, time, rate, volatility
Implied volatility: from market prices
Reflects market expectations

unit-10.title: Current economics
unit-10.description: Understanding unemployment, housing prices, credit crisis, financial bailouts, and European Union issues

finance-u10-l1-article.title: Learn: Unemployment
importantPoints: Unemployment: multiple types (frictional, structural, cyclical)
Unemployment rate: percentage of labor force
Limitations: doesn't count discouraged workers
Stimulus: cost per job analysis

finance-u10-l2-article.title: Learn: Housing price conundrum
importantPoints: Housing prices: multiple factors
Low rates, easy credit, speculation
Supply constraints, demographics
Policy and financial factors

finance-u10-l3-article.title: Learn: Credit crisis
importantPoints: Housing bubble led to credit crisis
MBS, CDOs amplified risks
CDS created systemic risk
Massive wealth destruction

finance-u10-l4-article.title: Learn: Paulson bailout
importantPoints: Liquidity vs. solvency: different problems
TARP: $700 billion bailout program
Systemic risk justified intervention
Moral hazard: ongoing concern
Comprehensive response needed

finance-u10-l5-video-2.title: United Kingdom vs Great Britain vs England primer

finance-u10-l5-video-5.title: How and why Greece would leave the Euro (part 3)

finance-u10-l5-video-6.title: Why Europe is worried about Greece

finance-u10-l5-article.title: Learn: European Union
importantPoints: Brexit: UK leaving EU
EU: economic and political union
Greek crisis: debt, austerity, bailouts
Grexit: considered but disruptive
Contagion risk worried Europe

economics-personal-finance.title: Economics & Personal Finance
economics-personal-finance.description: Understanding personal finance through economic principles

unit-1.title: Foundations of economics
unit-1.description: Understanding scarcity, opportunity cost, decision-making, factors of production, human capital, and economic systems

economics-u1-l1-article.title: Learn: Scarcity
importantPoints: Economics: study of choices with limited resources
Scarcity: unlimited wants vs. limited resources
Scarcity is permanent, not temporary
Forces us to make choices

economics-u1-l2-article.title: Learn: Costs and benefits
importantPoints: PPC: shows maximum production combinations
Opportunity cost: value of next best alternative
Points on curve: efficient
Increasing opportunity cost along curve

economics-u1-l2-practice.title: Practice: Opportunity cost and the PPC

economics-u1-l3-article.title: Learn: Decision making and unintended consequences
importantPoints: Optimal decisions: consider all costs and benefits
CBA: systematic decision-making approach
PACED: structured framework
Unintended consequences: unforeseen results

economics-u1-l3-practice.title: Practice: Decision making and unintended consequences

economics-u1-l3-quiz.title: Quiz: Decision making and unintended consequences

economics-u1-l4-article.title: Learn: Factors of production
importantPoints: Four factors: land, labor, capital, entrepreneurship
Human capital: knowledge and skills
Investment in human capital increases productivity
Entrepreneurship: innovation and risk-taking

economics-u1-l4-practice.title: Practice: Factors of production, impact of human capital on production, and the role of entrepreneurs

economics-u1-l5-article.title: Learn: Human capital and income
importantPoints: Investment in human capital: education, training
Benefits: higher income, better opportunities
Market value: what employers pay for skills
Develop high-value skills

economics-u1-l6-article.title: Learn: Economic systems
importantPoints: Command: government makes decisions
Market: individuals and businesses decide
Circular flow: money and goods circulate
Mixed economy: combination of both
Traditional: based on customs

unit-2.title: Producers and consumers in markets
unit-2.description: Understanding incentives, marketing, costs, revenue, profit, productivity, business organization, and market structures

economics-u2-l1-article.title: Learn: Incentives and marketing
importantPoints: Incentives: motivate behavior (positive and negative)
Marketing: influences consumer decisions
Consumer sovereignty: consumers determine production
Marketing can limit consumer sovereignty

economics-u2-l1-practice.title: Practice: Effects of marketing and incentives

economics-u2-l2-article.title: Learn: Cost, revenue, and profit
importantPoints: Cost: fixed and variable
Revenue: price × quantity
Profit: revenue - costs
Businesses maximize profit

economics-u2-l3-article.title: Learn: Productivity and economic growth
importantPoints: Investment in capital drives economic growth
Productivity: output per input
Higher productivity → more production
Productivity growth improves standard of living

economics-u2-l4-article.title: Learn: Business organization
importantPoints: Sole proprietorship: one owner, unlimited liability
Partnership: multiple owners, share profits
Corporation: legal entity, limited liability
Limited liability protects personal assets

economics-u2-l5-article.title: Learn: Market structures and competition
importantPoints: Perfect competition: many sellers, identical products
Monopolistic competition: differentiated products
Oligopoly: few sellers
Monopoly: single seller
Non-price competition: quality, service, branding

unit-3.title: The microeconomy and price systems
unit-3.description: Understanding demand, supply, elasticity, market equilibrium, and price controls

economics-u3-l1-article.title: Learn: Demand
importantPoints: Law of demand: price ↑ → quantity ↓
Substitutes: price ↑ → demand ↑
Complements: price ↑ → demand ↓
Normal goods: income ↑ → demand ↑
Inferior goods: income ↑ → demand ↓
Price change = movement; other factors = shift

economics-u3-l1-practice.title: Practice: Demand and the determinants of demand

economics-u3-l2-article.title: Learn: Supply
importantPoints: Law of supply: price ↑ → quantity ↑
Supply curve: upward sloping
Determinants: input prices, technology, number of sellers
Price change = movement; other factors = shift

economics-u3-l3-article.title: Learn: Elasticity
importantPoints: Elasticity: responsiveness to price changes
Elastic: quantity changes a lot
Inelastic: quantity changes little
Demand elasticity: substitutes, necessity, income proportion
Supply elasticity: time, inputs, storage, flexibility

economics-u3-l3-practice.title: Practice: Elasticity of supply and demand

economics-u3-l4-article.title: Learn: Equilibrium
importantPoints: Equilibrium: supply = demand
Equilibrium price and quantity
Surplus: price too high
Shortage: price too low
Shifts change equilibrium

economics-u3-l4-practice.title: Practice: Equilibrium and disequilibrium in markets

economics-u3-l5-article.title: Learn: Price controls
importantPoints: Price ceiling: maximum price, creates shortage
Price floor: minimum price, creates surplus
Interfere with market equilibrium
Reduce efficiency

unit-4.title: The role of government in markets
unit-4.description: Understanding public vs. private goods, property rights, and government redistribution of wealth

economics-u4-l1-article.title: Learn: Public vs private
importantPoints: Tragedy of commons: overuse of shared resources
Rival: use reduces availability
Non-rival: use doesn't reduce availability
Excludable: can prevent use
Public goods: non-rival and non-excludable

economics-u4-l2-article.title: Learn: Property rights
importantPoints: Property rights: legal right to own, use, dispose
Essential for market economies
Government enforces property rights
Government enforces contracts
Enables markets and investment

economics-u4-l2-practice.title: Practice: Government enforcement of property rights and contracts

economics-u4-l3-article.title: Learn: Redistribution of wealth
importantPoints: Transfer programs: redistribute income
Cash transfers: direct payments
In-kind transfers: goods/services
Social insurance: funded by contributions
Social safety net: help people in need

unit-5.title: Macroeconomic challenges
unit-5.description: Understanding macroeconomic indicators, aggregate demand and supply, and business cycles

economics-u5-l1-article.title: Learn: Macroeconomic indicators
importantPoints: GDP: total value of goods and services produced
Real GDP: adjusted for inflation
GDP limitations: doesn't measure quality of life
Inflation: general increase in prices
Unemployment types: frictional, structural, cyclical
Natural unemployment: frictional + structural

economics-u5-l2-article.title: Learn: The macroeconomy and economic challenges
importantPoints: Aggregate demand: total demand for all goods
Aggregate supply: total supply of all goods
AD-AS model: determines price level and output
Shifts affect income, employment, prices

economics-u5-l2-quiz.title: Quiz: The macroeconomy and economic challenges

economics-u5-l3-article.title: Learn: Business cycles
importantPoints: Business cycle: expansion, peak, recession, trough
Employment: varies with cycle
Inflation: often varies with cycle
Cycles caused by AD/AS changes, confidence, shocks

unit-6.title: Money, Banking, and Financial Markets
unit-6.description: Understanding money, financial institutions and markets, and the Federal Reserve

economics-u6-l1-article.title: Learn: Money
importantPoints: Money functions: medium of exchange, unit of account, store of value, standard of deferred payment
Characteristics: durable, portable, divisible, uniform, limited supply, acceptable
Commodity money: has intrinsic value
Fiat money: no intrinsic value, government decree
Fiat more flexible but requires trust

economics-u6-l2-article.title: Learn: Financial markets and institutions
importantPoints: Financial institutions: intermediaries between savers and borrowers
Financial markets: where assets are traded
Types: banks, credit unions, investment banks, insurance, mutual funds
Markets: stock, bond, money, forex, derivatives
Monetary systems: create and manage money

economics-u6-l3-article.title: Learn: The Federal Reserve
importantPoints: Banking crises led to Fed creation
Structure: Board of Governors, 12 regional banks, FOMC
Functions: monetary policy, bank regulation, payment systems
Financial stability, lender of last resort
Created 1913, evolved over time

economics-u6-l3-practice.title: Practice: History of banking and the Federal Reserve

unit-7.title: Economic stabilization
unit-7.description: Understanding monetary policy, fiscal policy, and government budgets

economics-u7-l1-article.title: Learn: Monetary policy
importantPoints: Monetary policy: Fed controls money supply and interest rates
Tools: open market operations, reserve requirements, discount rate
Expansionary: increase money, lower rates, stimulate
Contractionary: decrease money, raise rates, slow economy
Interest rates affected by policy, demand, supply, inflation, risk

economics-u7-l2-article.title: Learn: Fiscal policy
importantPoints: Fiscal policy: government use of taxes and spending
Expansionary: increase spending, decrease taxes
Contractionary: decrease spending, increase taxes
Automatic stabilizers: automatic adjustments

economics-u7-l3-article.title: Learn: Government budgets; revenue and expenditures
importantPoints: Tax structures: progressive, regressive, proportional
Mandatory outlays: required by law (Social Security, Medicare)
Discretionary outlays: set by Congress (defense, education)
State revenue: taxes, fees, federal grants
Deficit: spending > revenue
Debt: accumulated deficits

economics-u7-l3-practice.title: Practice: Government budgets revenue and expenditures

economics-u7-l3-quiz.title: Quiz: Government budgets; revenue and expenditures

unit-8.title: Global economy
unit-8.description: Understanding trade, exchange rates, and globalization

economics-u8-l1-article.title: Learn: Trade
importantPoints: Comparative advantage: lower opportunity cost
Specialization: focus on what you do best
Gains from trade: both countries benefit
Absolute vs. comparative advantage
Trade surplus: exports > imports
Trade deficit: exports < imports
Trade barriers: tariffs, quotas, subsidies

economics-u8-l2-article.title: Learn: Currency conversion
importantPoints: Exchange rate: price of one currency in another
Fixed vs. floating vs. managed float
Factors: interest rates, inflation, growth, stability
Appreciation: currency increases in value
Depreciation: currency decreases in value
Affects trade and investment

economics-u8-l3-article.title: Learn: Globalization
importantPoints: Globalization: increasing economic integration
Economic interdependence: countries depend on each other
Benefits: lower prices, growth, technology
Costs: job losses, inequality, environmental concerns
Trade agreements: reduce barriers
Types: FTA, customs unions, common markets

unit-9.title: Careers and education
unit-9.description: Understanding education as investment, paying for education, financial aid, and student loans

economics-u9-l1-article.title: Learn: Education and earnings
importantPoints: Education as investment: costs and returns
Benefits: higher income, better opportunities
Investment in human capital
Types: formal education, training, certifications

economics-u9-l2-article.title: Learn: Postsecondary education
importantPoints: Direct costs: tuition, fees, books
Indirect costs: transportation, opportunity cost
True cost: net price after financial aid
Grants: free money, don't repay
Scholarships: free money, don't repay
Student loans: must repay with interest
529 plans: tax-advantaged savings

economics-u9-l3-article.title: Learn: Cost of postsecondary education
importantPoints: Compare net price, not sticker price
Public: lower cost, state-funded
Private: higher cost, more resources
Community college: lowest cost, two-year
Certification: short-term, specific skills

economics-u9-l4-article.title: Learn: Financial aid
importantPoints: FAFSA: required for federal aid
Financial aid package: grants, scholarships, work-study, loans
Compare net price, not total aid
Accept free money first, loans last
Eligibility varies by type of aid

economics-u9-l5-article.title: Learn: Student loans
importantPoints: Loans: benefits and drawbacks
Repayment options: standard, graduated, extended, income-driven
Consolidation: simplify but may cost more
PSLF: forgiveness for public service
Deferment: temporarily postpone payments
Default: serious consequences

economics-u9-l5-practice-2.title: Practice: Student loan repayment and default

unit-10.title: Employment
unit-10.description: Understanding compensation, benefits, paychecks, non-typical pay, and hiring process

economics-u10-l1-article.title: Learn: Compensation
importantPoints: Employee benefits: non-wage compensation
Types: health, retirement, time off, insurance
Value: 30-40% of salary
Understand costs and options
Benefits vary by employer

economics-u10-l2-article.title: Learn: Paycheck
importantPoints: Gross pay: total before deductions
Net pay: take-home after deductions
Deductions: taxes, insurance, retirement
Paystub: shows all details
Review regularly for accuracy

economics-u10-l3-article.title: Learn: Non-typical pay
importantPoints: Non-typical pay: variable, less predictable
Types: commission, tips, contract, freelance
Tax implications: must report income
Self-employment tax: 15.3%
Quarterly estimated taxes
Track income and expenses

economics-u10-l4-article.title: Learn: Hiring process
importantPoints: Hiring forms: required documents
W-4: tax withholding form
I-9: employment eligibility verification
Complete within required timeframes
Update when circumstances change

unit-11.title: Banking
unit-11.description: Understanding banking institutions, bank accounts, account management, and interest

economics-u11-l1-article.title: Learn: Banking and financial institutions
importantPoints: Types: commercial banks, credit unions, online banks
Credit unions: member-owned, lower fees
Online banks: lower fees, higher rates
Consider: fees, rates, convenience, services
FDIC/NCUA insurance protects deposits

economics-u11-l2-article.title: Learn: Understanding bank accounts
importantPoints: Checking: daily transactions
Savings: earn interest, limited transactions
Money market: higher interest
CD: fixed term, highest interest
Opening: ID, SSN, initial deposit
Management: monitor, track, reconcile

economics-u11-l2-practice-2.title: Practice: Opening and managing bank accounts

economics-u11-l3-article.title: Learn: Tracking, reconciling and more
importantPoints: Regular tracking: know balance, avoid overdrafts
Catch errors and fraud
Reconciliation: match records with statement
Benefits: accuracy, control, security

economics-u11-l4-article.title: Learn: Interest
importantPoints: Interest: money earned on savings or paid on loans
Compound interest: interest on interest
Time is key factor in compounding
Rates affected by Fed policy, inflation, economy
Rising rates: good for savers, bad for borrowers
Falling rates: bad for savers, good for borrowers

economics-u11-l4-practice-2.title: Practice: The effects of interest rates

unit-12.title: Financial goals
unit-12.description: Understanding SMART goals, short/medium/long-term goals, and net worth

economics-u12-l1-article.title: Learn: SMART goals
importantPoints: SMART: Specific, Measurable, Achievable, Relevant, Time-bound
More effective than vague goals
Clear, trackable, realistic
Write goals down, review regularly

economics-u12-l2-video-1.title: Short, medium, and long term goals

economics-u12-l2-article.title: Learn: Short, medium, and long term goals
importantPoints: Short-term: within 1 year
Medium-term: 1-5 years
Long-term: 5+ years
Balance all three types
Prioritize and plan

economics-u12-l2-practice.title: Practice: Short, medium, long term goals

economics-u12-l2-quiz.title: Quiz: Short, medium, and long term goals

economics-u12-l3-article.title: Learn: Net worth
importantPoints: Net worth: assets - liabilities
Assets: what you own
Liabilities: what you owe
Measures financial position
Track over time

unit-13.title: Budgeting & saving
unit-13.description: Understanding budgeting, saving money, emergency funds, and reducing expenses

economics-u13-l1-article.title: Learn: Budgeting
importantPoints: Budget: plan for spending money
Start by tracking current spending
Build: income, expenses, savings
50-30-20 rule: needs, wants, savings
Balance: income = expenses + savings

economics-u13-l2-article.title: Learn: Saving money
importantPoints: Why save: emergencies, goals, retirement
How: pay yourself first, automate
Planned vs. unplanned expenses
Emergency fund: 3-6 months expenses
Start small, be consistent

economics-u13-l3-article.title: Learn: Reducing expenses
importantPoints: Compare deals: total cost, unit price, quality
Unit pricing: price per unit
Larger sizes often cheaper per unit
Multiple strategies to reduce expenses
Track spending, cut wants, negotiate

unit-14.title: Saving & investing
unit-14.description: Understanding risk and return, planning for retirement, and Social Security

economics-u14-l1-article.title: Learn: Risk and return
importantPoints: Risk: possibility of loss
Return: profit or loss
Risk-return tradeoff: higher risk → higher return
Stocks: higher risk, higher return
Bonds: lower risk, lower return
Diversification: spreads risk

economics-u14-l2-article.title: Learn: Planning for retirement
importantPoints: Plan early: longer life, inflation, healthcare
Estimate costs: 70-80% of pre-retirement income
Sources: Social Security, 401(k), savings, investments
Diversify income sources
Healthcare major expense

economics-u14-l3-article.title: Learn: Saving for retirement
importantPoints: Social Security: government retirement program
Funded by payroll taxes
Provides retirement, disability, survivor benefits
Amount based on earnings history
Not enough alone, need additional savings

unit-15.title: Consumer credit
unit-15.description: Understanding credit cards, credit scores, and credit management

economics-u15-l1-article.title: Learn: Credit cards
importantPoints: Credit card: borrow money to make purchases
Types: standard, rewards, secured, student
Compare: APR, fees, rewards, grace period
Schumer box: standardized terms
Good: convenience, rewards, build credit
Bad: high rates, debt risk, fees

economics-u15-l2-article.title: Learn: Credit score
importantPoints: Credit score: 300-850, measures creditworthiness
Factors: payment history (35%), utilization (30%), history (15%)
Higher score: better rates, easier approval
Improve: pay on time, reduce debt, keep old accounts
Takes time to improve

economics-u15-l2-practice-2.title: Practice: Factors that affect a credit score

unit-16.title: Loans and debt
unit-16.description: Understanding borrowing terms, loan sources, types of loans, debt management, and bankruptcy

economics-u16-l1-article.title: Learn: Terms of borrowing
importantPoints: APR: Annual Percentage Rate
Includes interest and fees
Shows true cost of borrowing
Allows comparison of loans
Lower APR = less cost

economics-u16-l2-article.title: Learn: Borrowing money
importantPoints: Sources: banks, credit unions, online, credit cards
Process: check credit, shop, apply, review, accept
Requirements: credit score, income, employment
Predatory lending: unfair practices, warning signs
Consumer laws: protect borrowers
Know your rights

economics-u16-l3-article.title: Learn: Types of loans
importantPoints: Secured: backed by collateral, lower rates
Unsecured: no collateral, higher rates
Secured: easier to get, asset at risk
Unsecured: harder to get, no asset at risk

economics-u16-l4-article.title: Learn: Debt
importantPoints: High rate method: pay highest rate first, saves money
Snowball method: pay smallest first, provides motivation
Debt repayment: systematic approach
Amortization: shows payment schedule
Debt management: budget, prioritize, avoid new debt

economics-u16-l5-article.title: Learn: Bankruptcy
importantPoints: Bankruptcy: legal process to eliminate/restructure debt
Chapter 7: liquidation, discharge debts
Chapter 13: reorganization, repay over time
Serious consequences: credit, future borrowing
Last resort, consider alternatives first

unit-17.title: Taxes
unit-17.description: Understanding taxes, local taxes, tax forms, and personal income taxes

lesson-17-1.title: What are taxes and why do we pay them

economics-u17-l1-video-1.title: What are taxes and why do we pay them

economics-u17-l1-article.title: Learn: What are taxes and why do we pay them
importantPoints: Taxes: money paid to government
Fund government services
Types: income, sales, property, payroll
Required by law

economics-u17-l1-quiz.title: Quiz: What are taxes and why do we pay them

economics-u17-l2-article.title: Learn: Local taxes
importantPoints: Local taxes: collected by local governments
Types: property, sales, income, utility
Sales tax: rate × price
Property tax: assessed value × rate
Fund local services

economics-u17-l3-article.title: Learn: Tax forms
importantPoints: Tax forms: documents to file taxes
Key terms: AGI, deductions, credits
W-2: wage and tax statement
Different boxes show different information

economics-u17-l3-practice.title: Practice: Tax forms and tax terms

economics-u17-l4-article.title: Learn: Personal taxes
importantPoints: Progressive taxation: rate increases with income
Tax brackets: income ranges with different rates
Not all income taxed at same rate
Marginal rate: rate on last dollar
Effective rate: average rate

economics-u17-l4-practice.title: Practice: Progressive taxation and tax brackets

unit-18.description: Understanding risk management, insurance basics, car insurance, health insurance, life insurance, property insurance, and estate planning

lesson-18-1.title: What is risk and how to manage it?

economics-u18-l1-article.title: Learn: What is risk and how to manage it?

economics-u18-l1-quiz.title: Quiz: What is risk and how to manage it?

unit-19.description: Understanding owning vs. leasing, car loans, and the true cost of car ownership
